西班牙将于周日举行一场可能势均力敌 的大选，其特点是意识形态分歧、极右势力的幽灵以及对被迫在暑假期间投票的愤怒。

投票于上午 9 点（格林威治标准时间 0700）开始，晚上 8 点（格林威治标准时间 1800）结束，届时将发布出口民意调查。专家表示，最终结果预计将由不到 100 万张选票和 350 个席位的议会中不到 10 个席位决定。

左翼在五月份的地方选举中惨败后，社会党总理佩德罗·桑切斯提前宣布了选举，但许多人对在炎热的夏季被要求投票感到愤怒。

西班牙邮政部门周五报告称，邮寄选票已超过创纪录的 240 万张，因为许多人选择在海滩或山区投票，而不是在炎热的家乡投票。

民意调查显示，这次选举很可能会为中右翼的人民党带来胜利，但为了组建政府，它需要与极右翼的Vox合作——这将是自 1970 年代弗朗西斯科·佛朗哥独裁统治结束以来首次有极右翼政党进入政府。

巴克莱在最近给客户的一份报告中写道：“维持现状和悬浮议会的可能性仍然存在，我们认为综合赔率可能为 50%。”他指出，PP 的优势微弱，而且民意调查和选民投票率总体存在不确定性。

桑切斯的少数派社会党（PSOE）政府目前与极左翼的我们能党（Unidas Podemos）联合，在苏马尔纲领下参加周日的选举，该政府通过了有关安乐死、 变性人权利、堕胎和动物权利的进步法律。

它警告说，如果反女权主义、注重家庭价值观的 Vox 成为下届政府的一部分，这些权利可能会被剥夺。

魅力十足的佩德罗·桑切斯，绰号“El Guapo”（英俊先生），他的总理任期以危机管理为标志——从新冠疫情及其经济影响到2017年加泰罗尼亚独立申请失败带来的政治破坏性后果。

专家表示，人民党领导人阿尔贝托·努涅斯·费乔在家乡加利西亚从未输过一次选举， 他利用自己愚钝的名声，将自己推销为稳定、安全的帮手，这可能会吸引一些选民。

新政府的组建取决于复杂的谈判，这可能需要数周或数月的时间，甚至可能以新的选举结束。这种不确定性可能会削弱马德里作为欧盟六个月轮值主席国的有效性，以及欧盟新冠疫情复苏基金的支出。

以色列总理本雅明·内塔尼亚胡在其办公室发布的视频声明中表示，他将在周六至周日之间安装心脏起搏器。

内塔尼亚胡在视频中说：“一周前，我安装了一个监控设备。该设备今天晚上发出蜂鸣声，说我必须安装心脏起搏器，而且我必须在今晚就这样做。” “我感觉很好，但我需要听医生的。”

73岁的内塔尼亚胡站在视频中微笑。他说，他的医生向他保证“明天下午”他就能出院。

他的办公室表示，他将在特尔哈肖默的谢巴医疗中心接受手术。 7月15日，内塔尼亚胡在那里住院过夜，他的办公室称，他在加利利海度假后没有适当保护自己免受热浪侵袭，导致脱水。

7月16日，医院证实了最初的脱水诊断，并表示，涉及皮下动态心电监护仪的额外测试发现内塔尼亚胡“心脏完全健康”，尽管该设备将使他的医疗团队能够继续监测他的健康状况。

玛雅·卢贝尔 (Maayan Lubell) 报道；保罗·西毛编辑; Sat, 22 Jul 2023 22:58:58 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/israels-netanyahu-says-he-will-be-fitted-with-pacemaker-overnight-2023-07-22/ https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/israels-netanyahu-says-he-will-be-fitted-with-pacemaker-overnight-2023-07-22/Reuters以色列内塔尼亚胡/健康（更新 1，PIX） Cambodia holds lopsided election ahead of historic transfer of powerSummary:
  • 韦斯特驳斥选举是一场骗局
  • 关注首相何时让位给儿子接任
  • 预计八月组建政府
  • CPP的运行几乎没有受到任何反对

柬埔寨周日举行一场一边倒的选举，这肯定会延长执政党的政治统治地位，为历史性的领导层过渡和世界上任职时间最长的总理之一的统治的结束扫清道路。

这场竞争实际上是一场单马竞赛，首相洪森领导的柬埔寨人民党（CPP）是一个拥有庞大资金的政治庞然大物，在对其竞争对手进行了长达数年的残酷镇压之后，却没有遇到任何可行的对手。

70岁的前红色高棉游击队员洪森已经领导柬埔寨38年，他无视西方对选举可信度的担忧，决心在他精心策划的过渡过程中防止任何障碍，以指定他的长子洪马奈为继任者。

直到周四，洪森才给出了交接的时间表，当时洪森暗示他的儿子“可能”在三到四个星期内担任首相，这取决于“洪马内是否能够做到这一点”。

45 岁的洪马内需要赢得国民议会席位才能成为总理，预计他将在周日的大选中实现这一目标。分析人士此前预计过渡将在中期进行，以便洪马奈有时间赢得公众和政治精英的合法性。

拉筹伯大学兼职研究员、一本关于柬埔寨民主的新书的作者戈登·科诺奇说：“在洪森身心健康的情况下移交权力，可以有力地保护他的儿子免受任何内部挑战。”

“现实是，只要洪森在，就没有人会反对洪马内。”

洪马奈很少接受媒体采访，也没有透露他对柬埔寨及其 1600 万人民的愿景。

他在纽约大学获得了经济学硕士学位，在布里斯托尔大学获得了经济学博士学位，并就读于西点军校，帮助他从柬埔寨军方晋升为陆军参谋长和武装部队副司令。

“和平而非战争”

主要大国将密切关注洪马奈是否会维持其父亲的独裁现状，或追求更大程度的自由化和更西方式的民主。

一个关键焦点将是他是否寻求引导柬埔寨脱离中国的轨道并修复与美国的关系，这种关系因他父亲的铁腕手段而长期紧张。

周五，洪马奈在数千名支持者面前的一次选举集会上宣布了“胜利日”，他们冒着雨给他摇滚明星般的待遇，高呼他的名字，爬上去自拍和亲吻。

他承诺投票给菲律宾共产党是“为了光明和繁荣的未来”，并警告未具体说明的“极端主义”企图“破坏选举”。

这些言辞与洪森自五月以来对对手的尖刻批评和先发制人的打击相呼应，其中包括因文书技术问题取消了菲共唯一有意义的竞争对手烛光党的资格。

当局还禁止自我流亡的反对派领袖桑兰西 (Sam Rainsy) 和 16 名盟友在二十年里投票和参加选举，因为他们敦促柬埔寨人销毁选票。

还有其他 17 个默默无闻的政党参加竞选，但在 2018 年的上次选举中没有一个政党赢得席位。

CPP的卖点是农村发展以及确保数十年战争后的和平与稳定，这有助于刺激到2019年平均增长率超过7%，创造服装制造和建筑业的就业机会。

83 岁的金边居民 In Som 说：“我希望下一任领导人能够确保和平，而不是战争。我们不希望这个国家再陷入战争。”

康诺奇表示，菲共取得压倒性胜利并不意味着选民完全支持执政党。

“他们没有其他选择，”他说。 “有许多柬埔寨人仍然致力于促进民主和人权。这可能不是他们的选举，但他们不会放弃。”

克里姆林宫表示，俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京和白俄罗斯领导人亚历山大·卢卡申科将于周日会面，两天前莫斯科警告称，对其邻国和最坚定盟友的任何侵略都将被视为对俄罗斯的攻击。

波兰本周早些时候决定将军事部队移至更靠近白俄罗斯边境的地区，以应对俄罗斯瓦格纳集团的部队抵达白俄罗斯。普京表示，莫斯科将采取一切手段对任何针对明斯克的敌意做出反应。

克里姆林宫表示，卢卡申科正在对俄罗斯进行工作访问，并将与普京讨论进一步发展两国“战略伙伴关系”。

卢卡申科虽然没有派遣自己的军队前往乌克兰，但在2022年2月允许莫斯科利用白俄罗斯领土对乌克兰发动全面入侵，此后频繁与普京会面。

此后两国举行了多次联合军事训练演习，6月卢卡申科允许俄罗斯用作核武器基地，此举遭到西方广泛谴责。

人们认为卢卡申科是西方的贱民，他的生存依赖于普京，这在基辅引发了人们的担忧，担心普京会迫使他加入新的地面攻势，并在俄罗斯步履蹒跚的乌克兰入侵中开辟一条新战线。

周四，白俄罗斯国防部表示，瓦格纳集团雇佣兵已开始在距离北约成员国波兰边境仅几英里的军事靶场训练白俄罗斯特种部队。

瓦格纳领导人叶夫根尼·普里戈任周三在一段视频中欢迎他的战士来到白俄罗斯，告诉他们暂时不会进一步参与乌克兰战争，但命令他们在训练白俄罗斯军队的同时为瓦格纳在非洲的行动积聚力量。

索诺拉州当局周六表示，墨西哥北部边境城市圣路易斯科罗拉多州的一家酒吧发生疑似纵火袭击，一名被驱逐的顾客用燃烧瓶纵火，造成 11 人死亡。

索诺拉州检察官表示，根据初步调查结果，嫌疑人是年轻男性，周六凌晨袭击发生时处于高度醉酒状态，并因不尊重酒吧女性而被赶出酒吧。

根据与亚利桑那州有漫长边界的州检察官的一份声明，他随后回来并向酒吧门口扔了一种燃烧弹。

声明补充说，11 名死者中有 4 人是女性，另有 4 人因伤势正在医院接受治疗。

报道称，当局正在努力抓捕嫌疑人。

戴夫·格雷厄姆报道；黛安·克拉夫特编辑; Sat, 22 Jul 2023 21:21:39 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/eleven-killed-suspected-arson-attack-bar-northern-mexico-2023-07-22/ https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/eleven-killed-suspected-arson-attack-bar-northern-mexico-2023-07-22/Reuters墨西哥火/ Nova Scotia floods cause 'unimaginable' damage; four people missing

官员周六表示，加拿大大西洋省份新斯科舍省遭遇50多年来最严重降雨，引发洪水，造成“难以想象”的损失，造成四人失踪，其中包括两名儿童。

这场从周五开始的风暴在短短 24 小时内就给部分地区带来了超过 25 厘米（10 英寸）的降雨量，与通常三个月内登陆的降雨量相同。由此引发的洪水冲毁了道路、削弱了桥梁并淹没了建筑物。

新斯科舍省省长蒂姆·休斯顿说：“我们面临着可怕而严重的情况。”他补充说，至少有七座桥梁必须更换或重建。

他在新闻发布会上说：“房屋遭受的财产损失……是难以想象的。”休斯顿表示，该省将寻求联邦政府的大力支持。

总理贾斯汀·特鲁多在多伦多告诉记者，他非常担心洪水，并承诺渥太华“将在那里”支持该省。

洪水是今年袭击加拿大的最新一起与天气有关的灾难。野火已经烧毁了创纪录的公顷面积，给美国带来了浓烟。本月早些时候， 大雨导致美国东部几个州发生洪水。

当局已宣布新斯科舍省最大城市哈利法克斯和其他四个地区进入紧急状态。

哈利法克斯地区市政府报告“道路和基础设施遭到严重破坏”，并敦促人们呆在家里，不要使用汽车。

哈利法克斯社交媒体上发布的图片显示，废弃的汽车几乎被洪水淹没，救援人员使用船只救援人员。

休斯顿援引警方的话称，两名儿童在他们乘坐的汽车被淹没后失踪。在另一起事件中，一名男子和一名青少年的汽车驶入深水后失踪。

一度有超过 80,000 人断电。

加拿大环境部预计该省东部地区将出现暴雨，并将持续到周日。

哈利法克斯市长迈克·萨维奇在新闻发布会上表示：“人们不应该认为一切都结束了。这是一个非常动态的情况。”他表示，该市遭受了“圣经中规模的降雨”。

加拿大广播公司气象学家瑞安·斯诺登 (Ryan Snoddon) 表示，哈利法克斯的降雨是自 1971 年飓风袭击该市以来最严重的一次。

周六早些时候，新斯科舍省北部当局下令居民撤离，因为担心圣克罗伊河系统附近的一座水坝​​可能会决口。他们后来取消了疏散命令。

大卫·永格伦报道；编辑：Daniel Wallis、Richard Chang 和 Paul Simao ; Sat, 22 Jul 2023 21:17:59 GMT https://www.reuters.com/business/environment/atlantic-canada-province-says-dam-could-breach-tell-residents-get-out-2023-07-22/ https://www.reuters.com/business/environment/atlantic-canada-province-says-dam-could-breach-tell-residents-get-out-2023-07-22/David Ljunggren加拿大洪水/（更新 4，电视） Cuban economy minister says no quick fix to devastating crisis

古巴经济部长亚历杭德罗·吉尔周六表示，古巴今年的经济增长率不到 2%，仍比疫情前水平低 8 个百分点，而农业、采矿和制造业等部门的生产则进一步落后。

吉尔在该国议会发表讲话时表示，包括农业、采矿和其他基本生产在内的第一产业较 2019 年下降了 34.9%，而制造业则下降了 20%。第三个行业，包括旅游、通讯和教育等服务业，下跌 4.9%。

严重依赖食品、燃料和其他进口的古巴将其出口收入下降50%以上主要归咎于美国的制裁和新冠病毒大流行，而出口收入是购买进口产品所必需的，同时也承认这个共产主义国家的市场化改革进展得太慢。

吉尔表示，今年迄今为止的出口收入为13亿美元，为预期的35.7%，而进口收入为44亿美元，也远低于古巴政府的预测。

这位部长表示，去年通胀率飙升 39%，今年通胀率飙升至 45%。许多经济学家表示，这一数字低估了通胀率，因为它没有充分考虑到因稀缺而不断增长的非正规市场。

古巴采取了加强价格控制来减缓通货膨胀，但迄今为止收效甚微，同时承认其他因素正在推高价格，例如生产率和产出低下。

“如果没有供应和生产，我们就无法实现有效的价格控制，”古巴议会议长埃斯特班·拉佐·埃尔南德斯在本周早些时候的一次会议上表示。

吉尔表示，这场危机“很复杂”，导致居民感到震惊、抗议并离开这个岛国，但他补充说，政府正在研究解决方案。

“古巴经济的逐步复苏尚未达到必要的速度，”他说。 “今年的增长非常缓慢，只有 1.8%，而且增长也不对称。换句话说，增长不会发生在生产部门。”

委内瑞拉移民弗兰卡·拉米雷斯 (Franca Ramirez) 说，在巴拿马丛林深处，一条湍急的河流冲破堤岸，委内瑞拉移民弗兰卡·拉米雷斯 (Franca Ramirez) 正争先恐后地爬到更高的地方，突然有东西引起了他的注意：一群年轻人正在拍摄风景。

这位前警察说他是为了逃离委内瑞拉的监禁和酷刑而感到惊讶。

他们进入达里恩峡谷已经超过一天的路程。巴拿马臭名昭著的丛林已成为成千上万徒步穿越美洲、希望最终到达美国的人旅程中的危险部分。

“我问他们是否是移民，”拉米雷斯上个月抵达墨西哥后说道。 “他们说不，他们正在丛林中创作内容和观光。”

这次相遇是两个不同世界在地球上最狂野的地方之一碰撞的罕见时刻。

丛林长期以来一直吸引着铁杆冒险家。 It is known as the 'gap' on Panama's Darien isthmus because it is the only missing section, running about 60 miles, on the Pan-American highway that stretches from Alaska to Argentina.

For decades, only the most intrepid of travelers ventured into this once impenetrable forest - dodging guerrillas and bandits; hunting for rare orchids or the great green macaw; and seeking the thrill of being one of the few brave enough to enter the wilderness where the road ends.

As adventure tourism has gained popularity worldwide - from climbing Mount Everest to riding a submarine to view the Titanic - tour agencies have also organized group excursions to the remote jungle.

"Tourism has been on the slow burner for decades in the Darien," said longtime Panamanian tour guide Rick Morales. "The jungle is special because it's powerful and humbling."

In recent years, parts of this jungle have become the site of humanitarian catastrophe. Hundreds of thousands of migrants from across the world, including as far as Afghanistan , and parts of Africa, cross the perilous terrain en route to the US border.

Blocked by visa restrictions from entering countries closer to the United States, a quarter of a million people traversed the lawless region last year.

At least 137 migrants died or went missing, including at least 13 minors, according to the UN's International Organization for Migration (IOM).

In addition to its lack of infrastructure, the Darien poses security challenges: the migrant routes in particular are controlled by criminal groups.

"The real number of migrants who have died and disappeared in the jungle is much, much higher," the IOM said in a statement to Reuters.

Tourists and migrants rarely meet face to face; the routes are almost always separated by dozens of miles. The migration routes hug the Darien's northern coast on the Caribbean Sea, which offers the most direct path to traverse the roadless jungle. The vast majority of tourism occurs closer to the Pacific Ocean.

Trip advertising does not mention the humanitarian crisis. Depending on the type of trip, tourist packages can range from a few hundred dollars to a few thousand dollars per person for a package that can include medical care, satellite phones, appropriate equipment and a cook.

Marco Wanske, a 31-year-old German who went on a 12-day jungle trek in January, said everyone in his group sustained minor injuries such as "jungle rot," a fungus that affects the feet, and one person had to be carried out by the group on the last day because she was unable to walk.

Migrants, at the mercy of smuggling gangs, often receive far less for their money.

Kisbel Garcia, a migrant from Venezuela, said she paid over $4,000 to a guide who promised to lead her and her four children and mother-in-law safely through the jungle. But instead of tourist-style protection, Garcia's guide abandoned them two days into the trek.

The family wandered six days through the mountains, passing corpses as they ran out of food, she says, and relying on scraps of blue cloth tied to trees by migrants to help mark the path for those who followed.

They survived.

"We migrants have to fight against all the risks without any kind of help," she said. "The Darien is hell."

CONFLICTING GOALS

The global adventure tourism market is booming, experts say, with its expenditures topping $680 billion, according to a 2021 report from the Adventure Travel Trade Association.

Social media has helped fuel the interest in visiting some of the world's most remote, inaccessible places, as travelers increasingly show off the risk and exclusivity of their journeys through selfies and TikTok videos.

Panama's government hopes to turn the Darien National Park into "the main eco-tourism destination in Central America," according to the country's 2020-2025 master plan for sustainable tourism.

Many naturalists and bird watchers are drawn to the park, which was named a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1981 due to its biodiversity, dramatic scenery and indigenous communities.

Even some migrants recognize the paradox of the jungle's attractions. "As I traveled, my heart was suffering, but my eyes were in delight," said Alejandra Peña, from Venezuela, who traversed the jungle with her three children, partner, and elderly parents last year while en route to the US border.

But some humanitarian aid groups have criticized adventure tourism in the Darien, saying marketing trips as if they were a test of survival skills is in bad taste and distracts from the suffering of migrants.

"The Darien is a humanitarian crisis zone, not a place for vacation," said Luis Eguiluz, who leads Doctors Without Borders (MSF) in Colombia and Panama.

The intersection of these worlds has prompted questions around ethical responsibility, experts say.

"For people who want to go to places that are more wild, what is our obligation?" said Lorri Krebs, an expert on tourism and sustainability at Salem State University in Salem, Massachusetts. "We need standards, we need the ethical or moral components in our tourism endeavors.”

In written responses to Reuters' questions about the ethics of such tours, the Tourism Ministry defended its efforts to boost international travel to the region, saying Panama "is blessed with sprawling jungles, mighty rivers, mountain peaks, endless coastlines, and diverse cultures." At the same time, it acknowledged a "catastrophic humanitarian crisis" in a separate part of the Darien due to migration.

Under pressure from the US government, Panama says it has stepped up efforts to stop migrants from crossing the jungle, including a campaign announced with the US in April. Even so, the numbers of migrants in the Darien has continued to rise.

The US State Department tells travelers to not enter a wide swath of the jungle that it says is commonly used by criminals and drug traffickers, and where emergency services are scarce.

BIG QUESTION MARK

Some tourists are already grappling with these kinds of questions.

"The migration crisis in this region was a big question mark for me before the trip," said German tourist Mark Fischer, who initially worried that the 100-km (62-mile) trek would be like "crossing the Mediterranean sea on a rubber dinghy for fun," alluding to another part of the world experiencing a migration crisis. His concerns were assuaged when he was told the trail would not overlap the migrants' route.

From the beaches of Greece to Texas' Big Bend National Park, which abuts the US-Mexico border, sunbathing and hiking often happen in areas where other people are risking their lives, Morales, the tour guide, said.

But in nearly 25 years of taking people into the Darien, he has never encountered migrants and said he plans his routes to keep these worlds apart.

"Personally, I could not put food in my mouth, or lie in my hammock protected from the elements, knowing that just a few hundred meters down the trail there is a hungry mother and a child spending the night sitting on the bare ground with no shelter from the rain and the insects," he said.

He added that trekkers often ask how they can help local communities.

COMMUNITIES PROFIT

Some indigenous people in the Darien – whose name, according to some experts, derives from the Spanish pronunciation of the original indigenous name for a local river - rely on tourism to bolster the economies of their local communities.

Travel Darien Panama is an Indigenous-owned tour operator that says on its website it aims to help fund schools and improve living conditions in their village. "We have been living here for decades, and these forests are literally our home," it says.

The firm's co-founder, Carmelita Cansari of the Darien's Embrera community, says part of the company's aim is to share their way of life: "We offer what we have in our community," she said. "Caring for nature, our culture, and dance."

Nina Van Maris, a 32-year-old outdoor enthusiast from Luxembourg, said she was unaware of the migration situation in the Darien when she signed up for an excursion run by German tour operator Wandermut.

She had seen an advertisement on Instagram while recovering from a debilitating rare illness that had left her temporarily unable to walk. The trip became motivation to fully recover.

"I thought to myself: when I can do that, I can do everything," Van Maris said.

In 2021, she traversed the jungle over ten days, from a village on the Balsas River in the heart of the Darien before ending at the Pacific Ocean.

"When I saw the beach, I thought to myself: I made it. I was crying, it was so emotional for me," she said. "The jungle gave me my life back."

在穆斯林占多数的马来西亚，同性恋是一种犯罪行为。人权组织警告称，该国对女同性恋、男同性恋、双性恋和跨性别者的不容忍现象日益严重。

在社交媒体上发布的视频中，希利在吉隆坡音乐节 Good Vibes 上向观众发表了充满脏话的演讲，批评马来西亚政府反对同性恋的立场后，有人看到希利亲吻贝斯手罗斯·麦克唐纳。

他说乐队曾考虑退出演出，但不想让马来西亚的粉丝失望。

据官方媒体报道，总理本月多次表示，他的政府将维护伊斯兰教原则。他曾表示，他的政府不会承认 LGBT 权利。

这艘独立级濒海战斗舰以澳大利亚皇家海军一艘巡洋舰的名字命名，该巡洋舰于 1942 年支援美国海军陆战队在夸达尔卡纳尔岛登陆时被击沉。该舰在悉尼港澳大利亚海军基地举行的仪式上入役，正式加入美国海军现役舰队。

The US Department of Energy on Friday proposed energy efficiency standards on water heaters it said would save consumers $11.4 billion on energy and water bills annually.

The standards on residential water heater efficiency, which are required by Congress, have not been updated in 13 years. Water heating is responsible for roughly 13% of both annual residential energy use and consumer utility costs, the DOE said.

The proposal would require the most common-sized electric water heaters to achieve efficiency gains with heat pump technology and gas-fired water heaters to achieve efficiency gains through condensing technology.

The standards, to take effect in 2029 if finalized, are expected to save nearly $200 billion and reduce more than 500 million metric tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions over 30 years, about equal to the combined annual emissions of 63 million homes, or approximately 50% of homes in the United States, the DOE said.

Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm said the proposal "builds on the unprecedented actions already taken by this administration to lower energy costs for working families."

A group including water heater maker Rheem, environmental group Natural Resources Defense Council and efficiency and consumer advocacy organizations issued a joint statement welcoming the new standards.

Tankless water heater maker Rinnai (5947.T) , however, said the proposed standards for its products were "technologically impossible" and would reduce consumer choice.

The administration of President Joe Biden, a Democrat, has issued proposed or final efficiency standards for 18 product categories so far this year.

Former President Donald Trump, a Republican, complained about efficiency standards for shower heads, saying that they interfered with the rinsing of his hair. His Energy Department eased energy standards on such fixtures. The Biden administration reversed the rule on shower heads in 2021.
